qas.question: In what institution do church courts still have relevant functions in secular society?
In what century did Saxons and Normans separate?
What type of law is not found in ecclesiastical systems in the modern day?
At which universities were canon law degrees abolished?
Who was responsible for banning canon law education from Oxford and Cambridge?
Where do church courts no longer function in secular society?

plausible_answers.text: mixed secular/religious county and local courts used by the Saxons

qas.question: What did the Normans split away from in the 1200s?
In one country is ecclesiastical matters part of a common law system?
What were ecclesiastical courts prior to the Reformation in England?
What universities offer Canon law degrees?

context: In <a0_0>the <b5_0>Church of England<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the ecclesiastical courts that formerly decided many matters such as disputes relating to marriage, divorce, wills, and defamation, still have jurisdiction of certain church-related matters (e.g. discipline of clergy, alteration of church property, and issues related to churchyards). Their separate status dates back to the <a1_0>12th<a1_0/> century when the Normans split them off from the <b6_0>mixed secular/religious county and local courts used by the Saxons<b6_0/>. In contrast to the other courts of <b7_0>England<b7_0/> the law used in ecclesiastical matters is at least partially a civil law system, not <a2_0>common law<a2_0/>, although heavily governed by parliamentary statutes. Since the Reformation, ecclesiastical courts in England have been <b8_0>royal courts<b8_0/>. The teaching of canon law at the <b9_0>Universities of <a3_0>Oxford and Cambridge<b9_0/><a3_0/> was abrogated by <a4_0>Henry VIII<a4_0/>; thereafter practitioners in the ecclesiastical courts were trained in civil law, receiving a Doctor of Civil Law (D.C.L.) degree from Oxford, or a Doctor of Laws (LL.D.) degree from Cambridge. Such lawyers (called "doctors" and "civilians") were centered at "Doctors Commons", a few streets south of St Paul's Cathedral in London, where they monopolized probate, matrimonial, and admiralty cases until their jurisdiction was removed to the common law courts in the mid-19th century.
